channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Desperate Gazans Are Raiding Aid Trucks, U.N. Official Says
item.description: Philippe Lazzarini, who heads the U.N. agency charged with aiding Palestinians, said Gazans are hungry and terrified, as he called for more deliveries of food, water and medicine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: People at the site of an Israeli strike on Thursday in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Putin Suggests He Has a Winning Hand in His War in Ukraine
item.description: The Russian leader, in his annual news conference, said he was open to peace talks but showed no hint of compromise. “Peace will come when we achieve our goals,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin arriving for his annual news conference on Thursday in Moscow, in a photo provided by Russian state media.

item.title: E.U. Leaders Agree to Open Membership Talks With Ukraine
item.description: After a bruising trip to Washington, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine welcomed a breakthrough in securing support from his allies as the war drags on.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Charles Michel, the president of the European Council, at a news conference following the announcement of accession talks for Ukraine and Moldova.

item.title: German Spy Official Goes on Trial Accused of Selling Secrets to Russia
item.description: The trial, held under stringent security conditions and expected to last months, caps one of the gravest espionage scandals in recent German history.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Judges and prosecutors at the Berlin court before Wednesday’s hearing. Under the trial’s security conditions, the chief judge surrendered his watch before entering.

item.title: To Fight Hamas, Israel’s Leaders Stopped Fighting One Another. For Now.
item.description: A team of rivals joined together in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s war cabinet. But beneath the veneer of unity, there are political differences and old resentments.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, left, with Yoav Gallant and Benny Gantz, two members of his war cabinet, in Tel Aviv in October.

item.title: Finland Closes Border With Russia Again
item.description: The country accused Russia of resuming an effort to funnel mostly African and Middle Eastern migrants into Finland in an effort to destabilize it.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Vaalimaa border checkpoint between Finland and Russia in Virolahti, Finland, has been closed again, as part of a diplomatic skirmish between Russia and Finland.

item.title: Takeaways From Putin’s Address on the Ukraine War and More
item.description: The Russian leader suggested that Western support for Ukraine was drying up and also gave his first comments about Evan Gershkovich, an American reporter detained in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia took questions for more than four hours.

item.title: A British Boy, Missing for 6 Years, Turns Up in France
item.description: Alex Batty, of Oldham, England, now a teenager, was found by a delivery driver walking on a rainy night in Chalabre. His mother and grandfather are wanted in connection with his disappearance.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: This photograph shows Alex Batty as he looked when he disappeared at age 11 while on vacation in Málaga, Spain, with his mother and grandfather. He is now 17.

item.title: Australian Court Throws Out Conviction of Mother Accused of Killing 4 Children
item.description: Kathleen Folbigg, who spent years in prison, was pardoned in June, after an inquiry found that her children had most likely died of natural causes.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Kathleen Folbigg, right, was embraced by a friend, Tracy Chapman, outside the New South Wales Court of Criminal Appeal in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Faces Critical Tests as It Duels With Russia for Stamina
item.description: With Western support for Kyiv softening and Congress holding up urgently needed aid, Vladimir Putin’s bet on outlasting Ukraine and its allies is looking stronger.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine visited President Biden on Tuesday. Mr. Zelensky also pressed Congress to pass a stalled spending bill that includes $50 billion more in security aid for Ukraine.

item.title: Russian Missile Attack on Kyiv Injures Dozens
item.description: Ukraine’s military said that it had shot down all the ballistic missiles targeting the capital, but that falling debris caused significant damage.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Debris littered a Kyiv playground on Wednesday after a Russian missile attack on the city.

item.title: Israel’s Netanyahu, Sparring With Biden on Gaza, Faces Risk and Reward
item.description: Israel’s prime minister said he disagreed with President Biden about what should happen in Gaza after the war, and analysts say he might try to use the rift to shore up domestic support.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, attending a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: Under Rules of War, ‘Proportionality’ in Gaza Is Not About Evening the Score
item.description: The concept, important for determining the legality of an act of war, is about weighing civilian harm against military objectives, not about achieving a balanced number of casualties.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians examining the rubble of destroyed buildings after an airstrike in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, in October.

item.title: At Least 12 Killed in Israeli Raid in West Bank, Palestinians Say
item.description: Israel said three soldiers were disciplined for video showing some of them singing a Jewish prayer in a mosque in Jenin, where Israeli forces concluded a 60-hour raid.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek, Ephrat Livni and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: People walking through the damaged streets of Jenin on Thursday after a multiday raid in the city by the Israeli military.

item.title: Brazil’s Congress Weakens Protection of Indigenous Lands, Defying Lula
item.description: While Brazil vows to fight climate change, lawmakers approved a law making it harder for Indigenous tribes to block deforestation, overriding a veto by President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance and Paulo Motoryn
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Indigenous people take part in a demonstration outside the Congress in Brasília, Brazil, in April.

item.title: Satellite Imagery and Video Shows Some Gazan Cemeteries Razed by Israeli Forces
item.description: The laws of armed conflict consider the intentional destruction of religious sites without military necessity a possible war crime.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:description: In Jabaliya, Gaza, vehicle tracks lead into Al-Faluja cemetery. It is one of at least six cemeteries that The New York Times identified as having been damaged or destroyed during the Israeli military advance.

item.title: Friday Briefing: U.S. Urges Israel to Scale Back Its War
item.description: Plus, why you might be an early riser.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The site of an Israeli strike yesterday in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Israel Says It Disciplined Soldiers Who Sang a Jewish Prayer at a Mosque in Jenin
item.description: With tensions in the area already high, the soldiers were “removed from operational activity” because of behavior that stood in “complete opposition” to the Israeli military’s values, it said.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Aaron Boxerman

item.title: Germany Accuses Four Men It Links to Hamas of Plotting Attacks on Jews
item.description: Three of the men were taken into custody in Berlin and another was arrested by Dutch police in the port city of Rotterdam, according to Germany’s justice minister.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Policemen in front of a house in Berlin in November during a raid against Hamas and another Palestinian organization banned in the country.

item.title: Biden Administration Urges Israel to Scale Down Its War in Gaza
item.description: The call for a more targeted phase in the war appeared to be the most definitive effort yet by the United States to restrain Israel in its retaliation against Hamas for the attacks it led on Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in northern Israel in October. The United States has urged Israel to draw down its ground campaign in Gaza.

item.title: Second Tanzanian Is Confirmed Killed in Oct. 7 Attacks in Israel
item.description: Tanzania’s foreign minister said that Joshua Mollel, an agricultural student, was “immediately killed after being kidnapped by Hamas.”
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Steven Mollel/Steven Mollel, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Joshua Mollel, whose death was announced, was part of an Israeli-sponsored agricultural program.

item.title: The North Sea Can Be Scary. But Maybe Not TikTok Scary.
item.description: A trend nobody asked for is here: Terrifying videos of unruly waves.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The North Sea can be turbulent. However, it’s probably not something to panic about from your couch 4,000 miles away.

item.title: U.S. Naval Officer Is Released From Jail in Japan After Yearslong Effort
item.description: The fallout over the case has strained diplomatic ties between Japan and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Derek and Suzi Alkonis holding a portrait of their son, Lt. Ridge Alkonis.

item.title: 3-Day Israeli Raid in Jenin Kills at Least 12, Palestinian Officials Say
item.description: Residents said Israeli military vehicles left the city on Thursday, signaling an end to the operation inside Jenin, a stronghold of Palestinian resistance in the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: People carry a body through the West Bank city of Jenin Thursday after a multiday raid by Israeli forces left at least 12 residents dead.

item.title: Bank of England Keeps Interest Rates at 5.25%, a 15-Year High
item.description: The Bank of England and European Central Bank both held their benchmark rates steady. Even though inflation has been slowing, they gave no indication of when rates would start to come down.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Terry Graham for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bank of England held rates at 5.25 percent, a 15-year high.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: An agreement at the U.N. climate summit.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Inside the Border Talks That Could Decide the Fate of Ukraine Aid
item.description: Negotiators are racing to reach a deal before Congress is expected to head home for the holidays at the end of the week.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: Migrants waiting to be processed by U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The White House has signaled that it is open to several Republican immigration proposals, but others could be difficult to accept.

item.title: Britain’s dangerous game of constitutional hardball
item.description: In seeking to override the U.K.’s highest court, Rishi Sunak’s government is following other nations in a trend that can damage democracy, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Migrants in Dungeness, England, after being rescued in the English Channel in August.

item.title: With a New Leader, Poland Prepares for a Course Change in Europe
item.description: Prime Minister Donald Tusk is sworn in and vows to try to invigorate flagging European support for Ukraine and push for “full mobilization” against Russia’s military assault.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Poland’s new prime minister, Donald Tusk, arriving for a summit at the European Council building in Brussels on Wednesday.

item.title: World Bank Warns Record Debt Burdens Haunt Developing Economies
item.description: Surging interest rates and waning financing options threaten a “lost decade” for poor countries.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The World Bank is warning that rising interest rates are making the debt burdens of poorer countries unsustainable.

item.title: 10 Israeli Soldiers Killed in Gaza
item.description: The military said that 10 of its soldiers had died in fighting in the north of the enclave.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:description: Israeli troops near the country’s border with Gaza on Tuesday.

item.title: Canadian Town Hosts Passengers From Diverted Delta Flight
item.description: The flight was forced to land because of a “mechanical issue,” the company said, leaving hundreds of passengers stranded.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: Military barracks in Happy Valley-Goose Bay, Canada, on Monday, where Delta Air Lines passengers spent the night after their plane was forced to land because of a mechanical issue.

item.title: In Real vs. Fake Christmas Tree Debate: Consider the Wildlife
item.description: It may seem counterintuitive to support the annual culling of trees, but environmentalists say Christmas tree farms have ecological benefits.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:description: Freshly cut trees ready for shipment at a farm in Oregon City, Ore.

item.title: The U.S. criticizes Israel for ‘indiscriminate’ bombing in Gaza.
item.description: bombing approach in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim

item.title: Held Hostage in Gaza, a Thai Worker’s Prayers for Freedom Come True
item.description: A Thai farmworker clung to hope during her nearly 50 days of captivity in Gaza by befriending a young Israeli girl and dreaming of reuniting with her boyfriend, who had also been abducted.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Muktita Suhartono and Lauren DeCicca
item.media:description: Bunthom Phankhong walking to the temple for his ordination ceremony in Udon Thani, Thailand, on Monday, as a gesture of thanks for his freedom. Mr. Bunthom and his girlfriend, Nutthawaree Munkan, were taken as hostages by Hamas on Oct. 7.

item.title: ‘She Gave Me Hope’: Thai Hostage’s Friendship With an Israeli Child
item.description: Thai hostage Nutthawaree Munkan was held by Hamas for nearly 50 days. During her time underground, a 5-year-old Israeli child gave her hope that she’d make it out alive.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling and Nicolas Axelrod
item.media:description: Nutthawaree Munkan speaking about her time in Israel at her boyfriend and fellow former hostage, Bunthom Phankong’s, family home in Udon Thani, on Monday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: President Biden’s warning to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, at his office in Jerusalem this week.

item.title: Japan Wants a Stronger Military. Can It Find Enough Troops?
item.description: A shrinking, aging population poses an obstacle as the nation tries to counter security threats from China and North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Hikari Hida and Chang W. Lee
item.media:description: Japanese troops during an amphibious landing exercise in Tokunoshima last month.

item.title: Tropical Cyclone Jasper Nears Australia Amid Wave of Extreme Weather
item.description: The storm is part of a stretch of wild weather the continent has been experiencing, which includes heat waves, fires and floods.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A downed tree in Cairns, Australia, on Wednesday as Tropical Cyclone Jasper approached the area.

item.title: Argentina’s New ‘Anarcho-Capitalist’ President Starts Slashing
item.description: Javier Milei has railed against Argentina’s government for years. In his first week in charge, he’s begun cutting it down.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Natalie Alcoba and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
item.media:description: President Javier Milei of Argentina at his inauguration Sunday in Buenos Aires.

item.title: U.N. General Assembly Votes for Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire, Countering U.S. Veto
item.description: About three-quarters of the body’s members voted in favor of the nonbinding resolution. The result underscored the isolation of Israel and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Dennis Francis of Trinidad and Tobago, the current president of the U.N. General Assembly, speaking before a vote on a nonbinding resolution demanding “an immediate humanitarian cease-fire” in Gaza.

item.title: Israel Announces Discovery of 2 Hostages’ Bodies in Gaza
item.description: The remains of Eden Zakaria, 27, and Master Sgt. Ziv Dado, 36, were repatriated to Israel, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Demonstrators carrying posters of Israeli hostages outside the Israeli parliament in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Biden Says Israel Is Losing Support
item.description: Plus, Volodymyr Zelensky pleaded for more aid in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: People searched through the rubble of damaged buildings following an Israeli air strike in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Tuesday.

item.title: Egypt’s Presidential Election Ends, With el-Sisi Expected to Win
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi is all but certain to come out on top after a three-day vote, with the war in Gaza turning the country’s focus from economic calamity to security.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Lining up to vote at a polling station in downtown Cairo on Tuesday.

item.title: Errant Airstrikes by Nigeria’s Military Have Killed Worshipers, Herders and Refugees
item.description: The U.S.-backed Nigerian military has been killing civilians in airstrikes at an alarming pace, security analysts and human rights advocates say, with little accountability.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Eric Schmitt and Ismail Alfa
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Victims of an army drone attack at a hospital in Kaduna, Nigeria, last week.

item.title: Rishi Sunak’s Rwanda Plan Is Approved by U.K. Parliament
item.description: The British prime minister’s contentious proposal to send asylum seekers to the African country moved forward a step, but it still faces potential stumbling blocks before becoming law.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has lashed his political fortunes to the Rwanda plan.

item.title: Who Is Donald Tusk, the Man Who Retook Power From Poland’s Right-Wing Leaders?
item.description: The opposition leader was endorsed by Parliament as the country’s next prime minister, unseating the right-wing Law and Justice party that had long denounced him as unfit to rule.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Donald Tusk speaking in Parliament in Warsaw, on Tuesday, a day after he was endorsed as prime minister.

item.title: Vatican Eases Rules on Preserving Cremation Ashes
item.description: Families may keep a “minimal” part of the ashes in a place of significance to the deceased, but the remainder must be placed in a sacred place such as a cemetery.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: An urn at a funeral home in Spain. The Vatican on Tuesday said that Catholic families could keep some ashes of relatives apart from the bulk of what would be buried.

item.title: Biden Warns Israel It Is ‘Losing Support’ Over War
item.description: The president’s words exposed a widening rift between his administration and that of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as casualties rise in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, at his office in Jerusalem this week.

item.title: U.N. Seeks Repayment of $63.6 Million From Former Official
item.description: The official was fired after investing millions in U.N. funds in housing and energy projects that went badly. He is contesting the order.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Vitaly Vanshelboim in 2016. He has been ordered to repay millions to the U.N. after he lost vast amounts of funds.

item.title: NOAA’s Arctic Report Card for 2023
item.description: Observations from researchers and residents, published annually in a report by NOAA, reveal a region grappling with rapid change.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: Ice in eastern Greenland: The continent’s ice sheet has lost mass every year since 1998.

item.title: At Least 23 Soldiers Killed in Attack in Pakistan
item.description: Tensions have been rising between Pakistan and Afghanistan, and violence in the border area has increased since Pakistan directed all undocumented foreigners to leave the country.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Rescue workers examined damage at the site of an explosion on the outskirts of Dera Ismail Khan, Pakistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: France Plans to Lure FIFA With the Promise of a Tax-Free Home
item.description: A plan to persuade sports federations to move to the country could save them millions. Supporters and critics of the proposal say it is intended to tempt one governing body in particular.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Daphné Anglès
item.media:description: FIFA headquarters in Zurich, the organization’s home since 1932.

item.title: Finland Partly Reopens Its Border With Russia
item.description: The Nordic country, which recently joined NATO, has accused Moscow of funneling migrants to their shared land border.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Vaalimaa crossing between Finland and Russia last week. The countries’ relationship deteriorated markedly after Moscow’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Kyivstar, Ukraine’s Largest Mobile Operator, Is Hit by a Cyberattack
item.description: The interruption could pose real danger in a country where many rely on phone alerts to warn them of impending Russian bombardments.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The headquarters of Kyivstar in Ukraine’s capital. The company said it was working to restore service after it was hit by a cyberattack.

item.title: No Aid for Ukraine Would Be a Gift to Russia, Biden Says as Zelensky Visits
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine traveled to Washington to make a last-ditch appeal for more help to fight Russia. But Republicans said they wouldn’t act without a border deal.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Catie Edmondson, Karoun Demirjian and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden and President Volodymyr Zelensky met on Tuesday at what may be Ukraine’s most vulnerable point in the war since it beat back Russia’s initial invasion.

item.title: UK Parliament’s Rwanda Vote Today, Explained
item.description: The British prime minister faced a test of his authority as he sought to protect his flagship immigration policy from threats within his divided party.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has made halting the arrival of migrants on the British coast in small vessels into a central test of his premiership.

item.title: Zulu King’s Reign Is in Doubt After South Africa Court Ruling
item.description: King Misuzulu’s claim to the throne in a storied monarchy has been the subject of a bitter family feud. The drama has captivated a nation that is home to about 14 million Zulus.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: King Misuzulu in September. A judge’s ruling in South Africa has raised fresh questions over his claim to the Zulu throne.

item.title: Lawmakers Call for Raising Tariffs and Severing Economic Ties With China
item.description: A bipartisan report recommended stripping China of the low tariffs the United States granted it two decades ago, among other actions.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A car assembly line in China. Many of the report’s recommendations may never be adopted, but it could provide a path toward some bipartisan legislation on China in the months to come.

item.title: After Referee Attack, Turkey Suspends All Soccer Matches
item.description: The postgame attack shocked a country used to heated atmospheres at soccer matches. The team president who threw the punch was arrested and later resigned his post.
item.dc:creator: James Montague
item.media:credit: Abdurrahman Antakyali/Depo Photos, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The referee Halil Umut Meler covered his face after being punched and knocked to the ground by Faruk Koca, center, the president of the Ankaragucu soccer club.
